  <td><div>Learning Activity: Introduction to R</div></td>

  <td><div>Tian Zheng</div></td>

<p>This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see <a href="http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com">http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com</a>.</p>

<h3><a id="user-content-a-very-brief-introduction" class="anchor" href="#a-very-brief-introduction" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>A very brief introduction</h3>

<ul>
<li>The S language was developed at AT&amp;T Bell labs by Rick Becker, John Chambers and Allan Wilks, starting as early as in the 1970s.</li>
<li>It was commercialized as S-PLUS.</li>
<li><code>R</code> is the open-source implementation of S. (google ``R programming language, wikipedia'' to read more).</li>
<li><p>From <code>R</code> FAQs: "Why is <code>R</code> named <code>R</code>?:</p>

<p>"The name is partly based on the (first) names of the first two     <code>R</code> authors (Robert Gentleman and Ross Ihaka), and partly a        play on the name of the Bell Labs language `S'."</p></li>
<li><p>(IMPORTANT!!) <code>R</code> is case-sensitive.</p></li>
</ul>

<h3><a id="user-content-getting-help-when-using-r" class="anchor" href="#getting-help-when-using-r" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Getting help when using <code>R</code></h3>

<ul>
<li> The official R website <a href="https://cran.r-project.org">CRAN</a> has a number of manuals online.</li>
<li> You can find help using the following <code>R</code> commands. </li>
<li> <code>help(sort)</code>--using exact command names and this command needs to be loaded already. same as <code>\sf ?sort</code>.</li>
<li> <code>apropos(</code><code>sor'')</code>--part of a command name.</li>
<li> <code>help.search(</code><code>sort'')</code>--search the description of commands.</li>
<li> <code>example(sort)</code>--show you example usage of a command.</li>
<li> <code>RSiteSearch(</code><code>sort'')</code>--search for online available help.</li>
</ul>

<h3><a id="user-content-data-in-r" class="anchor" href="#data-in-r" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Data in <code>R</code></h3>

<ul>
<li> In <code>R</code>, data and functions are called <code>R</code> objects.</li>
<li> Variables are stored as vectors in <code>R</code>.</li>
<li> A data set is usually in the form of a matrix, array or data frame.</li>
<li> Data frame can be made from vectors of the same length.</li>
<li> A list is a vector of <code>R</code> data objects.</li>
<li> Value assignment using <code>&lt;-</code> or <code>=</code>.</li>
</ul>

<h3><a id="user-content-basic-operations" class="anchor" href="#basic-operations" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Basic operations</h3>

<p>First let's load some data. Type <code>data()</code> in the <code>Console</code> window will open a list of all the datasets that were included with the standard installation. </p>

<p><code>R</code> uses basic syntax for simple arithmetics. In the following, the gray blocks are <code>R</code> codes you can type into the <code>console</code> window to try them out. The white blocks are outputs. </p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre><span class="pl-c1">2</span><span class="pl-k">+</span><span class="pl-c1">3</span>
<span class="pl-c1">3</span><span class="pl-k">^</span><span class="pl-c1">2</span>
<span class="pl-c1">4</span><span class="pl-k">/</span><span class="pl-c1">2</span>
log(<span class="pl-c1">10</span>)
sin(<span class="pl-c1">pi</span><span class="pl-k">/</span><span class="pl-c1">3</span>)</pre></div>

<p>You can create a variable as a vector of data values, with each element representing the value from an individual. $X=[X_1, \ldots, X_n]$. <code>length()</code> gives you the number of entries (i.e., the sample size). <code>mean()</code> calculates the sample average of the values. Similarly, we have other founctions that compute simple statistics such as <code>median</code>, <code>var</code>, <code>quantile</code>. <code>table</code> summarizes the counts of occurrences corresponding to unique values of <code>x</code>. </p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre><span class="pl-v">x</span><span class="pl-k">=</span>c(<span class="pl-c1">3</span>, <span class="pl-c1">1</span>, <span class="pl-c1">4</span>, <span class="pl-c1">2</span>, <span class="pl-c1">1</span>, <span class="pl-c1">4</span>, <span class="pl-c1">5</span>, <span class="pl-c1">1</span>,<span class="pl-c1">4</span>)
length(<span class="pl-smi">x</span>)
mean(<span class="pl-smi">x</span>)
table(<span class="pl-smi">x</span>)</pre></div>

<h3><a id="user-content-load-a-r-data-set" class="anchor" href="#load-a-r-data-set" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Load a R data set</h3>

<p>Now let's load a data set that comes with standard <code>R</code> installation: <code>InsectSprays</code>.</p>

<p>You can read about the documentation of this data set by typing <code>help(InsectSprays)</code> in the Console window. </p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre>data(<span class="pl-smi">InsectSprays</span>)
dim(<span class="pl-smi">InsectSprays</span>)</pre></div>

<ul>
<li><p>The function <code>dim</code> tells us the dimension of this data set. It is a $72 \times 2$ matrix, with each row being an experiment (individual) and each column being a variable (counts of insects, types of insecticide).</p></li>
<li><p>In this example, we refer to different columns of the data set by names of the column <code>InsectSprays[, "count"]</code>. We can also refer to the columns by number, <code>InsectSprays[,1]</code>.</p></li>
</ul>

<p>You can summarize the values of the variable <code>spray</code> (types of insecticide) using <code>table</code> and make a pie chart using the function <code>pie</code>.</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre>table(<span class="pl-smi">InsectSprays</span>[,<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>spray<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>])
pie(table(<span class="pl-smi">InsectSprays</span>[,<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>spray<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>]))</pre></div>

<p>You can summarize the values of the variable <code>count</code> (count of insects) using <code>summary</code> and visualize using <code>hist</code>.</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre>summary(<span class="pl-smi">InsectSprays</span>[,<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>count<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>])
hist(<span class="pl-smi">InsectSprays</span>[,<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>count<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>], <span class="pl-v">xlab</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>Insect Counts<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-v">main</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span><span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>)</pre></div>
</article>
